5. Do not drive until cleared by your orthopedic surgeon.

7. Swelling Management: Elevate your leg when resting and apply ice packs (wrapped in a towel) to the knee for 15-20 minutes several times a day, especially after activity or therapy. An elastic bandage may be used for compression if comfortable. Avoid NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen, etc.) unless specifically approved by your surgeon.
8. Anticoagulation: Continue Aspirin 325 mg twice daily for 4 weeks with food as prescribed to prevent blood clots. Continue Pantoprazole while on Aspirin to protect your stomach.
9. Wound Care: Keep the incision clean and dry. You may shower starting [Specify number of days, e.g., 48 hours] after surgery, but do not soak the incision in baths, pools, or hot tubs until cleared by the surgeon. Change your dressing daily or as instructed by home health. Watch for signs of infection: increased redness, warmth, swelling, or foul-smelling or excessive drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up appointment.
10. Home Health Services: Home health nurse and physical therapist will visit your home as arranged to monitor your progress, assist with dressing changes, medication review, and continue your physical therapy program.
11. Activity: You are weight bearing as tolerated on the right leg with an assistive device (walker or cane) as needed. Continue the exercises taught by physical therapy. Avoid strenuous activity, heavy lifting, or twisting motions of the knee until cleared by your surgeon. Progress your walking distance and independence with assistive devices as your strength and comfort allow.

Physical Therapy Instructions:
- Weight bearing as tolerated on the right lower extremity.
- Use assistive device (walker/cane) until cleared by PT/surgeon.
- Continue home exercise program focusing on range of motion, quadriceps and hamstring strengthening, and gait training.
- Mobilize frequently throughout the day.

- Primary Care Physician: Follow up as needed to review hospital stay, medications, and manage chronic conditions.

Avoid smoking or exposure to secondhand smoke and other respiratory irritants. Ensure you have an adequate supply of oxygen if prescribed for home use.

History of Present Illness:
This ___ year old male patient presented to the Emergency Department following a fall at home earlier today. He reported immediately experiencing severe pain and swelling in his right ankle and lower leg, rendering him unable to stand or walk. He denies head injury, loss of consciousness, or other trauma. He has a history of symptomatic right knee osteoarthritis, which has limited his mobility, and he notes the fall was likely related to unsteadiness due to his leg pain. He was transported via ambulance to the hospital. Imaging revealed a displaced transverse fracture of the shaft of the right fibula along with associated soft tissue injury. Given the nature of the fracture and absence of significant instability or open injury, non-surgical management was initiated with immobilization and pain control. He was admitted for pain management, assessment of neurovascular status, safe mobility planning, and education regarding his injury and recovery.

Past Medical History:
Right knee osteoarthritis (primary, severe)
Hypertension
Dyslipidemia
Obstructive Sleep Apnea (CPAP at night)

Lives at home with spouse. Non-smoker. Occasional alcohol use. Requires assistance for some daily activities due to baseline knee pain.

Positive for cardiovascular disease and arthritis.

Physical Exam:
General: Alert, oriented, comfortable at rest in hospital bed.

*   Immobilized in a walking boot.
*   Right knee with limited range of motion due to chronic osteoarthritis, but pain controlled at rest.
*   Right ankle/foot within boot: Palpable pulses (dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial) are strong. Capillary refill brisk. Gross sensation intact distally. Mild swelling noted around ankle visible above boot line. No open wounds or skin breakdown observed.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopedic service following presentation with a right fibula fracture and associated soft tissue injuries sustained in a fall. Initial assessment confirmed the displaced transverse fracture of the fibula shaft. Due to the characteristics of the fracture, a decision was made for non-surgical management with immobilization. A walking boot was applied.

Pain management was initiated utilizing scheduled oral analgesics and PRN medications, achieving adequate pain control throughout the hospitalization. The patient's neurovascular status of the right lower extremity was closely monitored and remained stable, with intact pulses, sensation, and capillary refill distally.

Due to the lower extremity injury necessitating limited weight-bearing on the right ankle and the patient's pre-existing severe right knee osteoarthritis, mobilization presented a significant challenge. Physical Therapy evaluated the patient and provided training on safe transfers and ambulation using an assistive device (walker) with strict non-weight-bearing on the right lower extremity. The patient demonstrated ability to safely transfer to/from bed/chair and ambulate short distances with assistance.

Chemoprophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis was initiated given the lower extremity immobilization. The patient tolerated oral intake well and remained afebrile. His baseline medical conditions were managed and remained stable.

At the time of discharge, the patient reported manageable pain on oral medications, demonstrated safe non-weight-bearing transfers and mobility with a walker, and expressed understanding of discharge instructions. His clinical status allowed for safe discharge to home with necessary support.

- Left Knee: Mild effusion, warmth, pain with passive and active range of motion, crepitus. Tender to palpation along joint line.
- Left Ankle/Foot: Mild stiffness, bony prominence consistent with known fluorosis, stable.
- Left Forearm: Blister site clean and dry, healing well, no signs of infection.
Skin: Incision sites (if any) are clean and dry. No rashes except treated forearm blister.

Pertinent Results:
Complete Blood Count: Within normal limits.
Basic Metabolic Panel: Electrolytes and renal function within normal limits. Glucose controlled.
Imaging: Recent left knee X-rays reviewed consistent with severe osteoarthritis. Left ankle/foot X-rays reviewed consistent with skeletal fluorosis changes.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for management of severe left knee pain related to osteoarthritis, which was refractory to outpatient management. Upon admission, pain control was addressed and optimized with a combination of scheduled and as-needed oral and intravenous analgesics.

Physical therapy and occupational therapy evaluations were completed to assess functional limitations and develop a safe mobility plan. Gait training with an assistive device was initiated.

Given the persistent pain, a left knee arthrocentesis and intra-articular corticosteroid injection were performed under sterile technique. The procedure was well-tolerated. Post-injection, the patient reported a modest improvement in pain, allowing for improved participation in therapy.

The patient's other chronic conditions, including hypertension and dyslipidemia, were medically managed throughout the stay. The previously noted blister on the left forearm was monitored and kept clean and dry; it showed signs of healing.

Consultations were obtained with Pain Management and Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation services to assist with complex pain management strategies and long-term functional goals, taking into account the patient's history of remote injury sequela and skeletal fluorosis impacting the left ankle/foot.

Prior to discharge, the patient's pain was adequately controlled on an oral medication regimen, and he demonstrated safe mobility with the prescribed assistive device. He tolerated a regular diet and remained afebrile with stable vital signs. Discharge planning focused on continuation of pain management, structured physical therapy, and appropriate follow-up care.

Be aware of potential side effects (drowsiness, constipation) of opioid medication. Drink plenty of fluids and use stool softeners as directed to prevent constipation. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking opioid pain medication.

7. Warning Signs: Return to the Emergency Department or call your doctor immediately for any of the following: severe pain not controlled by medication, signs of infection (fever >101.5 F, chills, redness, swelling, warmth, or discharge from any site), sudden increase in swelling in legs, chest pain, difficulty breathing, or any other new or worsening symptoms or concerns.

Followup Instructions:
Follow up with primary care physician within 7-10 days. Follow up with Orthopedics as directed, typically within 2-4 weeks. Outpatient physical therapy referral provided. Consider Pain Management and PM&R follow-up as discussed.

Patient: ___
Admission Date: ___
Discharge Date: ___

Attending Physician: Dr. ___

Chief Complaint: Left wrist pain and deformity following a fall.

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Left wrist Irrigation and Debridement, Open Reduction Internal Fixation of Distal Radius Fracture.

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman admitted following a ground-level fall. She reports tripping at home and landing heavily on her left hand with the wrist flexed. She experienced immediate severe pain and noted a visible deformity of the left wrist with a break in the skin. Emergency medical services were called, and she was transported to the hospital. She has a history of symptomatic right knee osteoarthritis, which contributes to some gait instability.

Past Medical History:
Right knee osteoarthritis
Hypertension
Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (controlled with oral medication)
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)

Social History:
Lives alone in a single-story house with a few steps at the entrance. Reports being independent with activities of daily living prior to this injury, though mobility was limited by knee pain. Non-smoker, occasional social alcohol use.

Family History:
Non-contributory for skeletal conditions.

Physical Exam on Admission (Pertinent Findings):
General: Moderate distress, grimacing with movement of left arm.
Vital Signs: Elevated blood pressure (presumably due to pain), otherwise stable.
Left Upper Extremity: Obvious deformity and swelling of the distal forearm and wrist. Open wound noted over the dorsal aspect with visible bone fragments. Sensation intact distally, pulses palpable. Pain with any attempted movement.
Right Lower Extremity: Tenderness and limited range of motion in the right knee, consistent with known osteoarthritis. No acute findings related to the knee upon admission.
Neurological: Alert and oriented. No focal deficits noted apart from the injured limb.

Pertinent Results:
Initial X-rays: Displaced comminuted fracture of the left distal radius with dorsal displacement and associated soft tissue injury, consistent with an open Smith's fracture. Right knee films showed severe degenerative changes.
Laboratory Data: Initial CBC showed mild leukocytosis, likely stress/injury-related. Hemoglobin and hematocrit within normal limits initially, trended down slightly post-operatively but remained stable. Glucose levels elevated on admission but controlled with adjusted medication regimen. Chemistry panel unremarkable. Wound cultures obtained during surgery were negative.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted directly to the orthopedic surgery service due to the open nature of the left distal radius fracture. She was started on broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics immediately upon arrival in the Emergency Department. After initial stabilization and assessment, she was taken to the operating room on the day of admission for irrigation and debridement of the open wound and open reduction internal fixation of the distal radius fracture using a volar plate and screws. A sterile dressing and splint were applied post-operatively.

Postoperative management included continued IV antibiotics for 48 hours followed by transition to oral antibiotics based on clinical improvement and negative cultures. Pain was managed effectively with a combination of intravenous and subsequently oral analgesics. The surgical wound was checked daily and remained clean with minimal drainage. The patient required assistance with mobility and activities of daily living due to limitations from both her left wrist immobilization and pre-existing right knee pain. Physical and Occupational Therapy evaluated the patient and initiated gentle range of motion exercises for the elbow and shoulder and provided instruction on functional tasks adapted for her injuries. DVT prophylaxis was administered daily. Blood glucose was monitored closely and managed. At the time of discharge, the surgical wound was healing well, pain was controlled with oral medication, she was afebrile, and vital signs were stable.

Discharge Medications:
1. Oral Antibiotic (specific type) - prescribed for a 7-day course.
2. Oral Analgesic (e.g., acetaminophen/opioid combination) - for moderate to severe pain, PRN.
3. Oral Analgesic (e.g., acetaminophen) - for mild pain, scheduled or PRN.
4. Stool Softener - to counteract potential constipation from pain medication.
5. DVT Prophylaxis (e.g., low molecular weight heparin or aspirin) - prescribed for a specific duration.
6. Home medications (Antihypertensive, Oral Hypoglycemic, GERD medication) - continued as prior to admission.

Discharge Disposition:
Skilled Nursing Facility / Rehabilitation

Facility: ___

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Left Smith's fracture, open, distal radius, type IIIA (ICD-10: S52542C)
2. Unilateral primary osteoarthritis, right knee (ICD-10: M1711)

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3.
Level of Consciousness: Alert.
Activity Status: Non-weight bearing on left wrist (immobilized in splint/cast), partial weight bearing or weight bearing as tolerated on right lower extremity (limited by knee OA). Requires significant assistance for transfers and ambulation, utilizing a walker adapted for left hand non-use.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Follow up with the orthopedic surgery team (specifically the hand/wrist specialist) as scheduled for wound checks, staple removal, and fracture assessment.
2. Follow up with your primary care physician as recommended for overall health management and medication refills.
3. Keep the left wrist splint/cast clean and dry at all times. Do not remove it.
4. Report any increased pain not relieved by medication, fever (temperature >101.5°F), chills, increased swelling in the fingers, numbness or tingling in the fingers, changes in skin color of the fingers (pale or blue), foul odor or drainage from the cast/wound area, or any concerns about the surgical site.
5. Elevate the left hand above the level of the heart as much as possible to reduce swelling, especially in the first few days post-discharge.
6. Do not lift anything with the left hand. Use the right hand for tasks as permitted by knee pain.
7. Continue prescribed medications as directed. Take pain medication only as needed. Be aware that pain medication can cause drowsiness and constipation.
8. Continue exercises for the elbow and shoulder on the left side as instructed by therapy to prevent stiffness.
9. Follow activity restrictions and mobility guidelines provided by physical and occupational therapy regarding transfers and ambulation, considering both the wrist and knee limitations.
10. You will receive wound care and therapy services at the rehabilitation facility.

Physical Therapy Recommendations:
Focus on safe transfers and ambulation with assistive device, considering limitations of both left wrist and right knee. Maintain range of motion in unaffected joints.
Treatment Frequency: As per rehabilitation facility protocol.

Followup Instructions:
Scheduled orthopedic clinic appointment for wound check and staple removal typically 10-14 days post-operatively. Further follow-up appointments for fracture healing assessment will be scheduled at that time. Follow-up with primary care physician recommended within 1-2 weeks post-discharge.

Severe right arm pain and inability to use arm after fall.

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) of right radius and ulna shaft fractures on ___.

History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old male with a known history of symptomatic right knee osteoarthritis (OA) who presented after a ground-level fall at home. Immediately following the fall, the patient experienced acute, severe pain and deformity in his right forearm and wrist. He also noted increased pain in his right knee, likely exacerbated by the mechanism of injury or impact. Evaluation in the Emergency Department revealed displaced oblique fracture of the shaft of the right radius with overlying skin compromise (classified as an open fracture type IIIA), a nondisplaced segmental fracture of the shaft of the right ulna, and a nondisplaced fracture of the base of the right fourth metacarpal bone. Due to the complexity and open nature of the radius fracture, the patient was admitted for surgical management.

Past Medical History:
Right knee osteoarthritis (M1711)
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Former smoker

Social History:
Lives at home with spouse. Requires assistance with some ADLs due to pre-existing knee OA.

Family History:
Non-contributory

Physical Exam on Admission:
Alert and cooperative, in moderate distress due to pain.
Vital signs stable, afebrile.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
Musculoskeletal: Significant swelling, ecchymosis, and gross deformity of the right forearm and wrist. Open wound present over the radius fracture site. Limited range of motion due to pain. Apparent shortening and angulation. Right 4th metacarpal area tender to palpation. Right knee with some swelling and decreased range of motion consistent with chronic OA; pain aggravated by attempting weight-bearing. Neurovascular status distal to forearm injury appears intact.

Pertinent Results:
Initial X-rays of right forearm/wrist/hand: Confirm displaced oblique right radius shaft fracture with open wound, nondisplaced segmental right ulna shaft fracture, nondisplaced right 4th metacarpal base fracture.
Pre-operative labs (CBC, BMP, Coags): Within acceptable limits for planned surgery.
Post-operative X-rays: Demonstrates satisfactory alignment and fixation of radius and ulna fractures with plates and screws.
Wound culture: Pending on discharge, initiated appropriate broad-spectrum antibiotics based on gross contamination.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopedic Surgery service following evaluation in the Emergency Department. Intravenous antibiotics were initiated for the open radius fracture. After medical clearance, he was taken to the operating room on ___ for open reduction and internal fixation of the right radius and ulna shaft fractures, including thorough irrigation and debridement of the open wound. The procedure was performed without immediate complication. Post-operatively, the patient was managed with intravenous and then oral pain medications. Antibiotics were continued. Physical and Occupational Therapy evaluated the patient, initiating gentle range of motion exercises for uninvolved joints and providing instruction on transfers and mobility modified for limited use of the right upper extremity. Given the delayed healing noted on imaging of the right 4th metacarpal fracture (from previous encounter), it was managed non-operatively with immobilization via the forearm cast applied post-ORIF. The patient received daily subcutaneous heparin for DVT prophylaxis. The surgical incision site was monitored and remained clean and dry post-dressing changes. Pain was reasonably well-controlled with oral medication by discharge. Mobility was challenging due to the combination of the dominant upper extremity injury and pre-existing right knee OA, requiring significant assistance. Nutritional status was monitored, and he tolerated a regular diet. At the time of discharge, the patient was medically stable, afebrile, and deemed ready for transfer to a facility where he could receive further rehabilitation and skilled nursing care for his complex injuries.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Alert and oriented.
Level of Consciousness: Alert.
Activity Status: Non-weight bearing on right upper extremity. Requires significant assistance for transfers and mobility using left side support (walker or cane, adapted). Limited mobility due to right arm injury and pre-existing right knee OA.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Fracture Care: Keep the right arm immobilized in the cast as applied. Do not attempt to remove the cast. Keep the cast clean and dry. Do not insert anything down the cast.
2. Wound Care: The surgical wound was closed and covered. The nursing staff at the receiving facility will monitor the wound site for signs of infection or issues.
3. Pain Management: Take prescribed pain medication as needed. Note dosage and frequency. These medications can cause constipation; ensure adequate fluid intake and use prescribed stool softeners. Do not drive or operate machinery while taking opioid pain medication.
4. Activity Restrictions: NO weight-bearing or strenuous activity with the right upper extremity. Continue with physical and occupational therapy as ordered to maintain mobility and strength in other limbs and for adaptive strategies. Exercise caution with transfers and ambulation due to combined injuries and knee OA; use assistive devices as instructed.
5. Medications: Take all prescribed medications as directed at the skilled nursing facility. Discuss resumption of Aspirin with the facility physician. Do not take NSAIDs (like ibuprofen, naproxen, Celebrex) unless specifically approved by your orthopedic surgeon, as they can potentially impair bone healing.
6. Signs/Symptoms to Report: Notify the nursing staff immediately if you experience increased pain not relieved by medication, fever (>101.5 F or 38.6 C), chills, new or worsening redness/swelling/drainage around the cast edges or surgical site, numbness or tingling in the right hand or fingers, inability to move fingers, chest pain, shortness of breath, or calf pain/swelling.
7. Follow-up Appointments: An appointment has been scheduled with Dr. ___ in the Orthopedic Clinic for ___ (approximately 2 weeks post-op) for wound check, potentially staple/suture removal, and assessment of fracture healing. You will also need ongoing follow-up for the metacarpal fracture and your knee OA, which can be coordinated by the skilled nursing facility staff.

Physical Therapy/Occupational Therapy Recommendations:
Right upper extremity: Maintain cast integrity, monitor for skin issues. Focus on shoulder and elbow (if not restricted) range of motion. Gentle finger ROM exercises as tolerated.
Left upper extremity & Lower Extremities: Strengthening and conditioning exercises.
Mobility: Transfer training (bed to chair, etc.) and ambulation using adaptive techniques/assistive devices (e.g., walker with platform attachment) with minimal stress on the right side. Patient will require moderate to maximal assistance for transfers and ambulation initially.
Right Knee: Continue pain management and gentle range of motion exercises as tolerated within limitations imposed by upper extremity injury.

Followup Instructions:
Appointment with Orthopedic Surgeon, Dr. ___, on ___ at ___.
Coordinate ongoing care for chronic conditions (HTN, HLD, OA) with facility medical staff and primary care physician as appropriate.
Continue rehabilitation at skilled nursing facility as ordered.

He reports increasing stiffness, especially in the morning. **Brief Hospital Course:**
Mr. ___ was admitted for evaluation and management of acutely worsening right knee pain due to severe osteoarthritis. Upon admission, his pain was assessed, and a multidisciplinary approach was initiated. He received scheduled and as-needed oral analgesics, including acetaminophen and opioid medication, which provided some relief. Physical therapy was consulted and began daily sessions focusing on gentle range of motion, strengthening exercises, and gait training with a walker to improve mobility and functional status. Orthopedics was consulted, confirming the severity of the OA and discussing future options, including potential total knee arthroplasty, which the patient will consider as an outpatient.

Concurrently, the superficial frostbite on the right index finger was identified and managed conservatively with gentle warming and monitoring. No significant blistering or tissue damage occurred, and the area remained clean and pain-free.

Pain control for the knee improved significantly with the optimized regimen. The patient's mobility increased with physical therapy, allowing him to ambulate safely with assistance. His vital signs remained stable throughout the stay, and he tolerated a regular diet. The frostbite area showed signs of healing by the time of discharge.

**Discharge Instructions:**

Showering may be permitted after a specified period (follow specific surgeon instructions, typically several days post-op) – pat the incision dry gently afterward. Monitor the incision daily for signs of infection.
4.  **Activity:** Weight-bearing as tolerated on the right leg using a walker or other assistive device as recommended by physical therapy. Gradually increase activity as pain allows and guided by physical therapy. Perform home exercise program as instructed. Avoid strenuous activities, heavy lifting, twisting, or pivoting on the operative knee until cleared by the surgeon.
5.  **Swelling:** Elevate the operative leg frequently, ideally above heart level, to reduce swelling. Apply ice packs to the knee for 15-20 minutes at a time, several times a day, using a towel between the ice and skin.
6.  **Constipation:** Pain medications and decreased activity can cause constipation. Ensure adequate fluid intake, eat fiber-rich foods, and use stool softeners (Docusate) and laxatives (Senna) as needed.
7.  **Follow-up:** Schedule or confirm your post-operative appointment with Dr. ___'s office approximately ___ weeks after discharge for wound check and staple removal. Continue outpatient physical therapy as prescribed.

Physical Therapy:
Patient is weight-bearing as tolerated on the right lower extremity.
Utilizing a walker for ambulation.
Focus on quadriceps sets, gluteal sets, ankle pumps, knee range of motion exercises (flexion/extension).
Gait training with progression as tolerated.
Ambulate frequently throughout the day.

Followup Instructions:
Post-operative clinic visit with Orthopedic Surgery in approximately ___ weeks.
Initiate outpatient physical therapy starting within 1-3 days post-discharge.
Follow up with Primary Care Physician for ongoing medical management and medication refills (other than pain medication).
